1130.81.text:
At Google, we use the term,

And a potentially

1144.85.text:
And we see these broken down
into two main categories--

1148.32.text:

and those that exploit

1155.74.text:
With API abuse, we see
apps that use Android APIs.

1160.94.text:
They operate within the
Android security model

1163.68.text:
to perform a behavior that
could be considered harmful.

1168.47.text:
An example of this
would be a phishing app.

1170.88.text:
Most phishing apps aren't
exploiting the platform.

1173.75.text:
They're using standard
Android APIs and UI widgets

1177.05.text:
to draw a convincing-looking
login screen

1183.13.text:
And this category of app
in the realm of API abuse

1186.25.text: is by far the most common.

1187.43.text:
Over 90% of PHAs that we
see are in the realm of API

1195.33.text:
The other category would
be described as exploits.

This is where you're taking

that has been

An example of this

where people root their device,

where you might break outside

1214.48.text:
And this is less common,

1217.59.text:
And if you're running an Android
device that has got the latest

1220.26.text:
security patches, typically,
these sorts of PHAs

1226.33.text:
Nearly every PHA we see

it's frankly much

1230.42.text:
simpler to do that

2152.66.text:
This is one example

So the sensor network
is fundamentally

2161.92.text:
this feedback loop

2169.86.text:
In a sense, SafetyNet is

device after the app

is installed to make sure

And the changes in

2180.63.text:

2186.03.text: Some of them are listed here.

For example, exploit attempt

2192.24.text:

in the middle attacks,

that sort of thing
that, SMS denials,

2197.07.text:
and the core system

We perform statistical analysis
on top of this, and, of course,

2206.70.text:
operating at such huge
scale across over a billion

2209.46.text:
Android devices allows
us to spot anomalies

2214.69.text:
So this is one
scorer that features

2217.35.text:
in the scorer engine called
the dead or insecure score.

2222.47.text:
And what this tracks is how
often devices disappear off

2226.11.text:
our radar once an
app is installed.

2228.90.text:
Typically, we expect that
when you install an app,

2231.26.text:
that device should
carry on checking back

2233.10.text:
in with the sensor
network the next day

2235.10.text:
and the next day
and the next day.

2237.71.text:
And so we measure
for each app what

2239.65.text:
the probability of that device
checking back in the next day

2242.20.text:
is, and so we look and compare
that with the ecosystem

2245.89.text:
Of course, there is
some drop-off every day

2248.95.text:
Maybe I'm going to go
and buy a new phone.

2250.91.text:
But for apps where that differs
significantly from the norm,

2256.54.text:
we can go and
investigate that app

2259.24.text:
or very clearly identify
that the app was

2264.07.text:
And so this is what
we use to go and flag

2265.87.text:
new apps that cause
devices to go dark,

2268.84.text:
maybe because they try
and turn off SafetyNet,

2270.76.text:
or maybe they
break the device so

2272.26.text:
fundamentally that the user
has to go and factory reset it.

2276.09.text:
This has been very effective at
detecting new rooting campaigns

2281.20.text:
that we've looked at, such
as Hummingbad or Ghost Push.

2284.55.text:
And we published a
blog post about this,

2286.22.text:
so if you want to go
and search for it,

2287.23.text:
you can just search for
dead or insecure score.

2292.92.text:
Of course, we're
not just limited

2297.68.text:
Machine learning is playing
an increasingly key role

2300.29.text: in how we find harmful apps.

2304.42.text:
What you see here is
a clustering of apps,

2306.97.text:
of harmful apps based on their
install patterns generated

2311.17.text:
with a neural network
using TensorFlow.

2314.52.text:
This uses the technique
called word embeddings, which

2317.27.text:
has pioneered in the field of
natural language processing,

2320.86.text: but applying it to apps instead.

2323.24.text:
In a sense, the order in
which apps are installed

2326.78.text:
is quite similar to the
order in which words

2332.05.text:
And so we can use
the ordering an app

2333.59.text:
installs to discern something
about the apps themselves.

2340.08.text:
So the result of
this neural network

2343.99.text: is a vector for every app.

2347.07.text:
And app vectors are positioned
in vector space, such that apps

2350.14.text:
that share common contacts or
attributes or patterns show up

2354.04.text:
in a similar area
or vector space.

2357.82.text:
So for example, we'd expect
to find all the messaging apps

2360.24.text:
showing up in one part of vector
space or all of the gaming apps

2365.64.text: And this is true for PHAs too.

2368.49.text:
So in this 2D embedding,
you see here we've

2370.96.text:
colored in all of the
potentially harmful apps

2376.27.text:
And you see that they cluster
in sometimes quite tight groups.

2380.65.text:
For example, in the top left,
we have a light blue section.

2383.92.text: Those are all SMS fraud apps.

2386.79.text:
So hopefully, you
can see how we're

2388.33.text:
able to use this very
powerfully to detect

2390.10.text:
new types of harmful
behavior for a new app

2392.83.text:
that we haven't yet
been able to classify.

2394.92.text:
If we see that it's embedding,
and vector space shows up

2398.92.text:
within that cluster, we
can begin to highly suspect

2401.92.text:
that app is also being part

2407.26.text:
Approaches like these are
greatly improving our ability

2416.25.text:
So let's take a look
at the attestation API.

2418.24.text:
This is one of the
most frequent APIs

2423.34.text:
that I discussed with
enterprises and developers.

2425.68.text:
I think it could be
powerful to use maybe

2427.39.text: for some of your use cases too.

2430.07.text:
This screen here
shows Android Pay

2432.19.text:
deciding that it hasn't been
able to determine the device

2434.56.text:
security sufficiently
to be able to run.

2438.40.text:
They use the attestation
API to determine this.

2442.43.text:
Many apps have
questions, such as,

2444.41.text: is the app talking to my server?

2448.46.text: Can I trust the platform APIs?

2453.51.text:
Is my app running
on a rooted phone?

2456.82.text:
It is the SafetyNet
attestation API

2458.85.text:
that allows you to assess the
security and compatibility

2462.25.text:
of the Android environments in
which your apps are running.

2468.63.text:
So I'll briefly talk you
through how this works.

2471.46.text:
At a high level, what happens
is you'll call the attestation

2474.04.text:
API on a device, and then
we all run through SafetyNet

2479.25.text:
a series of checks to come to
a decision about the device

2483.75.text:
The result will come
back from a Google server

2486.18.text:
as a signed statement
as to the device

2491.07.text:
And then you can inspect
that signed statement

2498.30.text:
to decide whether or not
you're going to trust

2503.35.text:
So you need both client and
server side implementations.

2508.04.text:
So you begin by calling the
attest method of SafetyNet API,

2510.67.text:
also in Google Play Services,
with a single use token that

2516.62.text:
That token will have
been sent by your server.

2520.26.text:
And then that's the
end of what you're

2521.84.text: going to do on your device.

2523.19.text:
When you get the result back,
you send that to your server.

2525.75.text:
As you're using the
attestation to decide

2527.60.text:
if you trust the
device, you don't

2529.09.text:
want to be doing any checks
on the device itself.

2537.10.text:
So now on the server side,
you pass back this result.

2539.74.text:
It's in the form of
adjacent web signature.

2542.59.text:
And first, you want
to validate the JWS.

2545.47.text:
So the first step is validating
the SSL certificate chain

2549.24.text:
and checking that the leaf
certificate matches what was

2556.54.text:
And then you'll verify
that that certificate

2559.15.text: was used to sign the JWS.

2562.64.text:
Now you can look at the
actual contents of the JWS,

2564.76.text:
which I'm showing
on the right here.

2566.26.text:
So you'll check
the nonce matches

2569.74.text:
You'll check the
timestamp is acceptably

2575.71.text:
And then you can check the
details about the app itself,

2578.62.text:
so you can check, does the
package name of the app

2582.58.text:
Does the signing certificate
hash match my own app?

2587.08.text:
Even does the digest
of the APK file

2589.45.text:
itself match the
APK that I produced?

2592.37.text:
And this helps you
determine on your server

2594.16.text:
whether the Android app that is
talking to you is really yours.

2601.55.text:
Sometimes we won't include
the APK information,
